The patient’s history of significant intraoperative blood loss and the fact that the pain is crampy and associated with an urge to defecate also support this diagnosis. The other options are less likely causes, as sigmoid colon outpouchings (diverticulitis) usually cause pain in the lower left quadrant, atherosclerosis of intestinal vessels is rare, and Clostridioides difficile infection usually presents with diarrhea and fever rather than bloody bowel movements and abdominal pain.
